headline: Hail and Farewell

headline: Headliners
lead_paragraph: When Dean Rusk left the Government last January after serving eight years as Secretary of State, he found he was unable to follow the usual route of Cabinet members into a highly paid job. His back ground qualified him for academe; but his defense of the Vietnam war made him a pariah on northern campuses, and his liberalism on civil rights (and his daughter's marriage to a Negro) made him unwelcome in the South. So he had to content himself with recording memories under a grant from the Rocke feller Foundation. Finally, last week, a job came through. The University of Georgia, after heated con troversy within the state's Board of Regents, hired him as a professor of international law. “I'm honored,” Mr. Rusk said with customary restraint, and he talked of “going back home” where he was born on farm.

The command also reported three instances of firing and shelling attacks by enemy gun ners yesterday from positions inside the demilitarized zone, the first attacks from the zone in more than two months. One shelling resulted in an unspeci fied number of Americans wounded but none killed, Unit ed States headquarters said.

headline: 2 RADICALS OFFER CONTRAST AT TRIAL
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 8—Two di vergent wings of the American radical movement went on dis play today at the Chicago con spiracy trial.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: ARMY NEWSMAN DISPUTES CHARGES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18—The Army broadcaster who accused the United States com mand of censorship last week end took issue today with court martial charges that have been lodged against him in connec tion with a previous incident.

headline: Thieu Says U.S. Combat Troops Cannot All Be Withdrawn in '70
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 9 — President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that it would be “impossible and impractical” to withdraw all American combat troops from South Vietnam in 1970.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. PLAN ON TALKS SPURNED BY HANOI
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 8 — The United States today revived a proposal to begin “restricted” sessions of the Vietnam peace talks as “a way of ending sterile de bate.”
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Sweden Aids Red Cross
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 9 (Reu ters) — The Swedish Govern ment today allocated $775,000 to the International Red Cross for humanitarian aid to Viet nam. The sum was requested by the international organiza tion, which will decide how it will be divided between North and South Vietnam, the Foreign Minister here said.

headline: U.S. Reports 109 of Foe Killed in Battle
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 9—American infantrymen supported by tanks, artillery and air strikes today reported having killed 109 North Viet namese and Vietcong soldiers in two days of fighting on the slopes of a mountain overlook ing the sprawling American base at Tayninh.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: MILITARY NEWSMEN SHIFTED IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 9 (AP) — Two military newscasters who accused the United States command of cen sorship were transferred today from the American radio and television network to other du ties within the command in Saigon.

headline: A ‘Bathroom Debate’ at Chicago Trial
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 9 — When histories of the Chicago con spiracy trial are written, to day's proceedings will probably go down as “The Great Bath room Debate.”
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: CONVICTIONS OF 2 IN PROTEST UPSET
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Jan. 9 (AP)— The United States Court of Ap peals for the Fourth Circuit re versed today the convictions of two persons arrested during antiwar demonstrations at the Pentagon two years ago.

headline: Nixon Flies to Massachusetts for Birthday Dinner Cooked by Daughter
lead_paragraph: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 9 — The convenience of jet travel and the prerogatives of the Presidency made possible a Nixon family reunion tonight in a small apartment near the Smith College campus. The oc casion was the President's 57th birthday.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETNAM KILLINGS LAID TO KOREANS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9— The former director of a pri vate research project in Viet nam said today that his inter viewers turned up evidence in 1966 that South Korean forces had murdered “hundreds” of South Vietnamese civilians.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: War Protester Loses Case And Gets 10‐Day Sentence
lead_paragraph: A 40‐year‐old hospital ad ministrator whose suit to have the war in Vietnam declared unconstitutional was dismissed in United States District Court earlier this week, was given 10 days in jail yesterday for causing a disturbance in the court.

headline: Nixon Planning to Name A New Envoy to Sweden
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Reu ters)—President Nixon is plan ning to name a new ambassador to Sweden soon, filling a diplo matic post left vacant for a year because of Washington's displeasure with Swedish sym pathy for North Vietnam. The State Department spokesman, Robert J. McCloskey made the disclosure today but refused to say who the new envoy would be.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If one were looking for conceptual turning points in the long course of American involvement in Asia, they might be found in two Presidential “backgrounders”— one held by President McKin ley, tormented over his decision to turn the Philippines into an American colony, and the other held 70 years later by Presi dent Nixon, tormented by an American war in Vietnam.
author: —John W. Finney

headline: Judge Commutes Sentence Of Man in Court Protest!
lead_paragraph: A 33‐year‐old hospital admin istrator who was jailed Fri day for causing a disturbance in United States District Court was released after several hours when Judge George Rosling commuted his 10‐dav sentence.

headline: HUMPHREY SCORES NIXON LEADERSHIP
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey attacked the Nixon Administration yesterday for operating “like a corporate structure” without “a vision of the seventies.”

headline: ‘Let's Say It Right’
lead_paragraph: The story of the Vietnam war comes in large part from military press officers, and how that story sounds often depends on what terms they use. Recent ly the United States Command indicated it did not like some of the terms being used and issued to its briefing officers a “guidance” directive banning cer tain terms and substituting others. The directive, titled “Let's Say It Right,” included the following changes:

headline: JUDGE UPHOLDS BAN ON G.I. PUBLICATION
lead_paragraph: CLINTON, N. C., Jan. 10 (AP) —A Federal judge has ruled that a military base commander has the right to restrict dis tribution of publications that he believes would undermine the morale of his men.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Elections in Japan

headline: DEMOCRATS FOUND TO FAVOR PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10 — The Gallup Poll has found that Democrats tend to favor withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam immediately o by the end of the year, while most Republicans favor with drawal only when the South Vietnamese are able to handle the war themselves.

headline: Thieu Gets Tougher With Everyone
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—It was not so much what President Nguyen Van Thieu said at his press confer ence last week as the way he said it that left the 200 news men in his audience with the distinct impression that he had adopted a new, hard line on everything from American troop withdrawals to the motives of his political opposition.
author: —Terence Smith

headline: Rattle Data Won't Cite Distances From Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10 (Reuters)—United States war communiques no longer give the distances of battles from Saigon because the United States command is “trying to eliminate the overemphasis” on their closeness to the capital, a United States spokesman said today.

headline: After Vietnam, What? Industry Has Optimistic View
lead_paragraph: If the longest war in the history of the United States, the war that has helped po larize the nation into two camps and radicalize the young people, came to an end tomorrow, the impact on industry and business with little or no direct connection with the war effort would be minimal.
author: By Lee Kanner

headline: McCarthy Feted at Moscow Avant‐Garde Theater
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 10—Eugene J. McCarthy, the Senate's most celebrated poet, talked about the human condition, verse and ice hockey today with Andrei Noznesensky, the poet, and Yuri Lyubimov, director of the avant‐garde Taganka Theater.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: NEW DATA ACCUSE KOREAN SOLDIERS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10—A staff member of the Rand Cor poration said today that inter views he conducted in Viet nam late in 1966 turned up “hearsay evidence” of South Korean troop atrocities against South Vietnamese civilians.

headline: ENEMY SHELLINGS IN VIETNAM CAUSE SEVERE U.S. LOSSES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10—Enemy troops, firing 15 mortar rounds, inflicted severe casualties last night on Ameri can troops at an artillery base about 300 miles northeast of Saigon, according to United States headquarters.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Capture of Foe's Radio Monitoring Post Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 12 (AP) — American forces have uncover ed a major North Vietnamese communications center just north of Saigon that intercepted at least 1,400 operational mes sages and presumably com promised some field operations, official sources disclosed today.

headline: U. S. Troops Apply Pressure in Tayninh
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11 (Reuters) — United States soldiers were reported today to be continuing to press North Vietnamese troops in Tayninh Province northwest of Saigon. A United States spokesman said that 15 of the enemy had been killed in the area where 61 North Vietnam ese were said to have died in heavy fighting yesterday.

headline: It's Not the War News
lead_paragraph: In Paris during the First World War, the lieutenant in charge of Stars and Stripes, the grandfather of Army newspa pers, placed his managing edi tor, Pvt. Harold W. Ross, under arrest because of an argument over the correct use of a comma. Ross stood in the corner for awhile; then the lieutenant freed the future edi tor of The New Yorker because he didn't know how to put out the paper himself.
author: By Herbert Mitgang

headline: Laotian Front Has Hanoi Unit
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 11 (Agence France‐Presse)—An information bureau of the pro Communist Laotian Patriotic Front was opened here last night.

headline: U.S. TEAM IN PARIS RENEWS PRESSURE FOR PEACE TALKS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 11—The United States delegation to the Viet nam peace talks here is step ping up its pressure on the Communist side to negotiate an end to the war.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Plight of City People

headline: Laird Disclaims Koreans' Acts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11—Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that alleged atrocities by South Korean troops against South Vietnam ese civilians were not the re sponsibility of the United States command in Vietnam.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: Upside‐Down Flag Leads L.I. Housewife to Trouble
lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 12— A 26‐year‐old mother of two who had been searched, handcuffed and fingerprinted before being released in $500 bail for having flown the American flag upside down in an antiwar protest was freed from bail today and will stand trial on March 17.
author: By Roy R. Silver Special to The New York Times

headline: In The Nation: Talking Tough in Saigon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12—The toughest problem for President Nixon in pursuing “Vietnamiza tion” of the war may not be those domestic critics who think that, at best, the scheme will take too long and, at worst, that it is a plan for fighting a proxy war ad infinitum. Presi dent Thieu of South Vietnam is likely to cause more trouble than any of these unheeded voices.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: PARK PERMIT BAN LINKED TO DALEY
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 12—A de fense witness said today that he had been told that Mayor Richard J. Daley was blocking permits for demonstrators to sleep in parks two weeks be fore the 1968 Democratic Na tional Convention here.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: The New U.S. Ambasador to Sweden
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — Last April, a small group of militant students at Hamp ton Institute in Virginia de manded the resignation of the college's president; Dr. Jerome Heartwell Holland.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: McCarthy, Mrs. Binh Confer for Two Hours
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 12 (Reuters)— Senator Eugene McCarthy, who led an election‐year po litical revolt against Amer ican policy in Vietnam, con ferred today with Vietcong and American peace negoti ators

headline: Wide Observances Due on King Birthday Thursday
lead_paragraph: Martin Luther King's birth day will be observed with spe cial programs and memorial services by many organizations in the city on Thursday, al though the day is not a legal holiday.
author: By Barbara Campbell

headline: Next U. S Pullout Includes First Division
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12—The United States mil itary command announced here today that the First Infantry Division would be the major combat element to leave South Vietnam in the third phase of President Nixon's withdrawal program.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: 4 Pilots' Wives Abandon Attempt to Get Soviet Aid
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (Reuters)I —The wives of four American pilots missing in Vietnam said today that they were abandon ing attempts to seek the help of Soviet officials in getting news of their husbands.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Soviet Mideast Aims

headline: Washington: The Big‐Power Nightmare
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13—An odd thing is now happening in world politics. The small and middle nations, which used to be afraid that the United States and the Soviet Union would blow up the world, now seem to be afraid that Washington and Moscow will get together and organize the world in their own national interests and against the interest of many other nations.
author: By James Reston

headline: THIEU ASSAILS FOES WHO SEEK COALITION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13 (Reuters)—President Nguyen Van Thieu today again strongly criticized advocates of coalition or neutralism in South Vietnam, calling them political witches and racketeers.

headline: Tex Ritter Backs War Policy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) —Tex Ritter, former Western singing star and a candidate for the Republican nomination for the Senate from Tennessee, said today he agrees with President Nixon's Vietnam pol icy. Mr. Ritter, 65 years old, came to Washington to meet party leaders, Tennessee Re publicans and reporters.

headline: Defoliation Said to Cut Cambodian Rubber Output
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13— Two teams of scientists have reported that they found that United States defoliation efforts in the Vietnam war had damaged rubber production in adjacent Cambodia.

headline: No Major Tet Flare‐up Seen
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13—Analysts here say they do at expect enemy forces to mount a major military offen sive during the three‐day Tet, or Lunar New Year, holiday next month.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Base Near Danang Captured by U.S. Troops
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13 (AP)—United States troops, pursuing a North Vietnamese force in foothills west of Tam ky, captured a freshly built base camp today in an area where enemy troop concentra tions have been renorted.

headline: Agnew Gives Australia Partnership Vow
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 13 — Vice President Agnew greeted Australians today with a pledge of partnership in the Pacific and a friendly wave to antiwar demonstrators.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Analysis of Student Protests Finds Most Nonviolent, With New Left a Minor Factor
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13—The firpt complete study of student protests last year at colleges and, universities shows that most were nonviolent and did not interrupt routine, that new left groups were a minor fac tor, and that the protesters were less concerned with the Vietnam war and related is sues than with conditions on the campuses.
author: By John Herbers Special to The New York Times

headline: McCarthy Sees Hanoi Aide, Returning to U.S. Today
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 13 (AP)—Sena tor Eugene McCarthy spent four and a half hours in “cor dial and informative conversa tion” today with Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief delegate to the Paris peace talks, a spokesman for Mr. CcCarthy said.

headline: LAWYER HERE TO AID SAIGON G.I. NEWSMAN
lead_paragraph: Leonard Boudin, counsel for the National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee, an nounced here yesterday that he would represent Specialist 5 Robert Lawrence, the Army newscaster who was removed from his television assignment in Saigon after he had charged the military authnrities with censoring of news broadcasts.

headline: Bond Says Two Chicago Defendants Feared Police Violence Would Occur
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 13 — Julian Bond, the black state legis lator from Georgia, said today that Tom Hayden told him several months before the 1968 Democratic National Conven tion that he feared “police violence” here during the con vention.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Army Consolidating Songmy Inquiry at Georgia Base
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13— The Army announced today that it was going to transfer to Fort McPherson, Ga., or nearby bases most of the ac tive‐duty servicemen connect ed with the investigation into alleged atrocities at Songmy, South Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Assessing Blame in Massacres

headline: SONGMY INQUIRY WIDENED BY ARMY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON Jan. 14— The Army's investigation of the alleged massacre at Songmy has been widened to include 13 soldiers and 18 former soldiers, five more men than were pre viously known to be under scrutiny.

headline: Saigon Reports Defection
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (Reuters)—The chief of staff of the North Vietnamese Army's. Second Division has defected to the South Vietnamese side, a military spokesman said today. He added that Col. Dang Toa presented himself to a company of South Vietnamese militia men in Quangnam Province, 1.7 miles southwest of Danang yes terday.

headline: River Battle Near Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (AP)—Field reports said to day the crew of a United States Navy river patrol boat and Army helicopter gunships en‐ gaged 10 to 15 North Vietnam ese soldiers trying to cross the Saigon River about 18 miles north of the capital and killed eight of the enemy with ma chine‐gun fire.

headline: STATE INQUIRY ASKED IN PROTESTER'S CASE
lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 14— The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court and the State Attorney General were asked by the Nassau County Executive today to investigate the treatment received in court by a 26‐year‐old mother of two who was arrested for flying the American flag upside down as an antiwar protest.

headline: Senate Committee to Open Vietnam Hearings Feb. 2
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 — The Senate Foreign Relations Committee plans to open its public hearings on the Vietnam war on Feb. 2, committee sources said today.

headline: Buddhist Students' Peace Rally In Saigon Is Dispersed by Police
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 15—The Saigon police broke up a meeting this morning at the An Quang Pa goda in which militant Bud dhist students had called on the people to rise up in a national campaign for peace.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Witness Says Police in Chicago Broke His Arm During Protest
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 14—A col lege student said today that his arm had been broken by Chi cago policemen as they pulled him from a statue in Grant Park during demonstrations at the 1968 Democratic National Con vention here.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) —The following servicemen from the New York area were identified by the Defense De partment today as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: THIEU IS PLANNING CHANGES IN ARMY
lead_paragraph: BANMETHUOT, South Viet nam, Jan. 14 (Reuters)—Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu said today he expected to announce a reorganization of South Viet nam's armed forces later this year.

headline: Senator Hart's Wife and Seven Others Go on Trial for Protest
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14— The wife of Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, and seven co‐defendants went on trial today for breaking Federal building violations by attempt ing to hold an ecumenical mass for peace inside the Pentagon last Nov. 13.

headline: AGNEW, IN CANBERRA, HOLDS NEWS PARLEY
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. I4—Vice President Agnew ap peased one set of Australian critics today but avoided a con frontation with another.

headline: Nassau Vows to Prosecute Sale Or Use of Peace Symbol on Flag
lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 15—The use of the American flag with the peace symbol displayed across its face was declared to be a violation of state law today by Nassau County District At torney William Cahn.
author: By Roy R. Silver Special to The New York Times

headline: Laird Says Defense Cuts Will Cost 1,250,000 Jobs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15— About 1,250,000 Americans will lose their jobs as a result of reductions in military man power and spending either already made or planned in the next defense budget, De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Says Nixon Criteria On Pullout Can't Be Met
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 15—Ha Van Lau, North Vietnam's repre sentative at the Paris peace talks, said at the 50th session of the talks today that President Nixon's three criteria for the withdrawal of United States forces “in fact can never be met.”
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: ALLIED FIRE BASE ATTACKED BY FOE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15—Enemy gunners are re ported to have fired about 100 mortar rounds into an allied artillery base near Cambodia and then launched a ground attack that died out after an hour of intense fighting. Allied soldiers killed 29 of the enemy, while suffering light casualties, military spokesmen reported here.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: FULBRIGHT TARGET OF AGNEW'S TAUNT
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Friday, Jan. 16—Vice President Agnew said here today that Senator J. William Fulbright “apparently has blown his cool again.”
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Foes of War Form Group to Forward Letters to P.O. W.'s
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 15—Oppo nents of the Vietnam war an nounced today the formation of a committee to “facilitate communication between serv icemen held in North Vietnam and their relatives in the United States.”

headline: Washington: Quarterback Nixon's ‘Game Plan’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15—That incorrigible football buff, Rich ard M. Nixon, has come to the end of the first quarter with his “game plan” intact. Like his friend Vince Lombardi of the Washington Redskins, he is sticking to fundamentals and controlling the ball.
author: By James Reston

headline: THIEU OPPOSITION IN SENATE UNITES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Jan. 16—Senator Tran Van Don and 14 other members of the South Vietnamese Senate announced today the formation of a political bloc that they said would become the nucleus of a wider opposition front.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) —The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: Decision Called Firm
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (Reu ters)—Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers said tonight that President Nixon's decision to end the United States com bat role in the Vietnam war was “irreversible” and would lead to the eventual removal of all American troops.

headline: SOUTH KOREA DENIES ATROCITY CHARGES
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 15 — The South Korean Defense Ministry denied today as “un founded” and “deplorable” the charges that South Korean troops had murdered hundreds of South Vietnamese civilians.

headline: SONG BY GUTHRIE BARRED AT TRIAL
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 15— Arlo Guthrie found out today you can't “get anything you want” in Judge Julius J. Hoffman's courtroom.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: PEACE MASS IS SAID ON PENTAGON STEPS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) —A peace fellowship group, in cluding two clergymen now on trial for an earlier incident, conducted a mass without in terference today on the steps of the Pentagon.

headline: Westmoreland Comments
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Jan. 16 (UPI)—Gen. William C. West moreland, former commander of United States forces in Viet nam, said today that the Army “is not trying to hide any thing” in the investigation of the alleged Mylai massacre.

headline: 16 Die Near Songmy As Vietcong Attack Hamlet of Refugees
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 16 (AP) — Vietcong guerillas invaded a hamlet near Songmy early today and hurled dyna mite charges into houses, kill ing 16 persons and wounding 21, an American spokesman said.

headline: Contract Breach Charged
lead_paragraph: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 16 (AP)—A breach of contract complaint against the Army was filed yesterday in Federal District Court by an attorney for one of the four soldiers charged in connection with the alleged Mylai massacres.

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) —The Pentagon today identifiedthe following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: How Big the Cutback?
lead_paragraph: The additional cutbacks in defense spending, sketched by Defense Secretary Laird the other day, need to be put in perspective lest they seem larger than they are. They amount only to the reductions in spending to come from a scaling down of opera tions in Vietnam plus a little more trimmed here and there from a bloated budget. They represent no fundamental shifts in strategy, much less any reorder ing of priorities.

headline: AGNEW, IN AUCKLAND, IS FIRM ON VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 16 (AP)—Vice President Agnew, winding up his Asian tour, declared tonight that the United States and its allies must stand firm in Vietnam and not be swayed by antiwar factions.

headline: 3 ‘Missing’ U.S. Servicemen May Be P.O.W.'s in North
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16— Three servicemen listed as missing in North Vietnam may be prisoners of war, according to new information received by the Defense Department.

headline: Topics: A Plan for a Progressive Cease‐Fire in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. The fundamental flaw in the Administration's program for Vietnamizing the war is that it does not facilitate the very compromise settlement that President Nixon has announced as his objective.
author: By Alexander L. George and John Wilson Lewis

headline: RADIO‐TV CENSORING DENIED BY PENTAGON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16—The director of information for the armed forces denied today that military officials censor the ra dio and television stations that broadcast news to United States servicemen overseas.

headline: Goodwin Tells Jury in Chicago He Knew No Plans for Violence
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 16—Richard N. Goodwin, an aide to Presi dent Kennedy and President! Johnson, testified today that he knew of “no plan for viol ence” by demonstrators at the Democratic Convention here in 1968.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Testimony on Mass At Pentagon Given By Senator's Wife
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) — Mrs. Philip A. Hart, whose husband is not only Michigan's senior Senator but also a ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, testified in a suburban Virginia Federal magistrate court today as a co‐defendant with seven other persons arrested for par ticipating in an unauthorized eucharistic mass in the con course of the Pentagon last No vember.

headline: Legionnaires Seek $200,000 for Calley Defense
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 16 (UPI) — American Legion mem bers here began today a na tional fund‐raising drive to col lect $200,000 for a legal de fense fund for Army Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr., accused of murdering 110 Vietnamese ci vilians.

headline: Student Says Refugees Toldof Korean Slayings
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16—A student at Saigon Uni versity said today that in 1966 he interviewed at least 100 refugees who told him stories or gave eyewitness accounts of indiscriminate killings and de struction by South Korean sol diers in Phuyen Province.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Youth Hostel to Be Given By U.S. Actor to the Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 — After 20 months of running a hostel for Saigon's shoeshine boys and homeless children, a 26‐year‐old actor and newsman, Richard Hughes, is turning his humanitarian en deavor into a purely Vietna mese‐run program.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Church Head to Aid Troops
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 17 (AP) —The Rev. Robert V. Moss, president of the two‐million member United Church of Christ, said today that he would spend Easter in Vietnam to “assist chaplains in minister ing to combat troops.” Dr. Moss, here for the dedication of the $8‐million Beatitudes Re tirement Home, said the soldiers bear burdens “far heavier than most of us realize.”

headline: Democrats Are Not Finding Nixon an Easy Target
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—As the 91st Congress returns this week for its second session, Congressional Democrats suddenly find them selves bereft of issues at the very time they are casting around for political points to use against a Republican Administra tion in the Congressional elec tions next fall.
author: —John W. Finney

headline: Wives of 4 Missing Fliers Seek Information in Laos
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 17 (AP)—The wives of four Amer ican fliers missing in Vietnam flew to Laos today to seek the assistance of North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao officials in obtaining information about their husbands.

headline: Six Aspiring Democrats Give State Preview at Syracuse Forum
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE, Jan. 17 — Six Democratic politicians who want to be Governor, United States Senator or State Attor ney General sought some early traction for their bandwagons today here in the icy heartland of New York.
author: By Francis X. Clines Special to The New York Times

headline: The Two Nations At Wesleyan University
lead_paragraph: THE old John Wesley House, a splendid campus landmark with white Ionic columns, turned into the Malcolm X House one sunny day last April. Overnight it became a conspicuous presence on the startled New England landscape. The sky did not fall and the earth did not tremble; neither did the alumni with draw their support. But Wesleyan, a small, estimable, historically white university in Middletown, would never be the same. “We have passed the point of no return,” says a Wes leyan administrator. “The blacks are here in force and they are here to stay.”
author: By Richard J. Margolis

headline: A Scenario For the Fireworks At Tet
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Will the enemy launch an offensive during the Tet Lunar New Year holidays next month?

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Credit for Nixon

headline: U.S. SAYS VIETCONG SHOT 2 PRISONERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 (AP) — The United States Command said today that the Vietcong had hauled two Amer ican captives from one village to another, placed them on ex hibition and then shot them to death.

headline: Hybrid Rice Helps Vietnamese Farms
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam— A middle‐aged man with mud‐stained ankles plods be hind a water buffalo in a landlord's flooded rice field, while hoping that the com batants on both sides of the war will leave him alone. headline: Report Shows U.S. Pays Taxes To Nations Getting Military Aid
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) —In a two‐year period, while the United States committed ex tensive sums for the war in Vietnam, South Vietnam col lected $28‐million to $34‐mil lion in taxes from the United States Government.

headline: 15 Football Stars Picked To Tour U.S. Military Bases
lead_paragraph: Four men who competed in a recent National and Ameri can Football League champion ship series are among 15 play ers named yesterday to tour United States military bases, hospitals and outposts in the far east, including the war zones of South Vietnam.

headline: Chicago Police Aide Says Ohio Professor Hit Him
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP)—A high police official testified to day that a Cleveland professor hit him and threw a traffic bar rier toward a sergeant in street disorders the week of the Democratic National Conven tion in 1968.

headline: AN ANTIWAR VOTE ASKED IN ASSEMBLY
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Jan. 27—Hoping for a lively debate, if not ap proval, 26 Assembly Democrats introduced a resolution today urging immediate withdrawal from Vietnam by United States troops.
author: By Francis X. Clines Special to The New York Times

headline: Elmira G.I. Killed in Vietnam
'68 YIPPIE PLANS STUNNED MAILER
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 27—“Wow!” said Norman Mailer when he first heard the Yippie strategy for the 1968 Democratic Nation al Convention here.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Weighs Tet Truce
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, Jan. 28 (AP) — President Nguyen Van Theiu is planning to order a cease‐fire for the Tet lunar new year but has not decided the length or timing, a Govern ment spokesman said today.

headline: Nixon and Wilson Discuss Major Issues
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27—In what has become an almost an nual rite of British‐American friendship, Prime Minister Wil son arrived here amid pomp and ceremony for a round of talks with President Nixon and other senior United States offi cials.

headline: U.S. COURT IS ASKED TO RULE ON FLAG USE
lead_paragraph: A Federal judge in Brooklyn said yesterday he would seek the convening of a three‐judge constitutional court to rule on the use of peace symbols in conjunction with the American Flag.

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) —The Pentagon announced to day the names of 19 American servicemen killed in Vietnam. The list included Specialist 4 Nathaniel Thomas, of the Army, of Elmira, N. Y.

headline: New U.S. Pullback From South Vietnam Is Beginning Today
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (AP)—The withdrawal of 50,000 more American troops will begin tomorrow with 3,000 marines from 19 units leaving over a five‐day period, the, United States Command an nounced today.

headline: Garden Thronged for Songfest In Aid of Vietnam Moratorium
lead_paragraph: A capacity crowd of 21,000 was at Madison Square Garden last night to see performers ranging in style from East Har lem to Las Vegas in a benefit for the Vietnam Moratorium Committee.
author: By Mike Jahn

headline: U.S. TROOPS UNCOVER BIG NEW ARMS CACHE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)—United States troops searching through a huge enemy arms cache in the jungles northwest of Saigon uncovered two and a half tons of arms and nearly 250,000 rounds of ammunition, American head quarters said today.

headline: 65% in Poll Support Nixon Policy on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 28— Support for President Nixon's. Vietnam policies is holding firm, the Gallup Poll reported today.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Transit as State Issue

headline: CENSORSHIP DENIED BY U.S. COMMAND
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)—The United States command today denied charges that unfavorable news reports were censored by the Armed Forces Vietnam Network.

headline: Chicago 7 Judge Bars Ramsey Clark As Defense Witness
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 —Judge Julius J. Hoffman barred Ram sey Clark, the former United States Attorney General, from testifying today as a witness for the defense in the Chicago conspiracy trial.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Casualties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) —The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

headline: BISHOP ODD HAGEN, LED METHODIST UNIT
lead_paragraph: Bishop Odd Hagen, president of the World Methodist Council since 1966, died yesterday after a short illness, according to word received from Stockholm. He was 64 years old.

headline: SAIGON ‘NEWSMEN’ WERE U. S. AGENTS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP) — American officials said today that two United States Government agents were infiltrated into the Saigon press corps but were withdrawn aft er their identity had been ex posed.

headline: News Summary and Index
lead_paragraph: Responding to the firing at an Ameri can reconnaissance plane over North Viet nam, American fighter‐bombers attacked a missile site inside North Vietnam on Wednes day, the United States command in Saigon announced early today. One of the attack ing planes and a rescue helicopter were shot down. Washington officials said the incident did not reflect a change in American pol icy. [Page 1, Column 1.]

headline: Two Testify That Professor Was Beaten at Convention
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP)— Two free lance photographers testified yesterday that they saw a deputy superintendent of police beat an antiwar leader during street violence the week of the 1968 Democratic Na tional Convention.

headline: Bunker Says Enemy Remains A ‘Force to Be Reckoned With’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 29—The United States Ambas sador, Ellsworth Bunker, today described 1969 as a year of meaningful progress in South Vietnam, but conceded that the enemy “is still a military force to be reckoned with.”

headline: ‘Silent Majority,’, U.S.I.A. Film, Fails To Stir Foreigners
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29— “The Silent Majority,” a con troversial film produced by the United States Information Agency to show that President Nixon has ample public sup port for his policies in Vietnam, has been less than a smash hit abroad.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Antiwar Group Planning Feb. 14 Parley on Tactics
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) —A student antiwar group an nounced today a conference, open to the entire antiwar movement, in Cleveland Feb. 14–15 to plan a spring ac tion campaign.

headline: SEALE, PEACEABLE, RETURNS TO TRIAL
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 29—Bobby G. Seale returned to the Chicago conspiracy trial today and fi nally got a chance to speak out at length.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: No Relief for the Riders...
lead_paragraph: The much‐abused riders on all the mass transit lines in the metropolitan area are on the verge of open rebel lion. The latest affront is the Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority's order for higher fares on the Long Island Rail Road, effective tomorrow—an order so certain to stir additional outrage that the Long Island trainmen are threatening to strike unless they get police protection.

headline: U.S. PLANES MAKE RETALIATORY RAID IN NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 30—United States fighter‐bombers attacked an antiaircraft missile base 90 miles inside North Vietnam on Wednesday after an unarmed American reconnaissance plane was fired upon by missiles, they American command announced here early today.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: 4 U.S. AGENTS POSED AS SAIGON NEWSMEN
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Jan. 29 (AP)—Four United States Government in vestigators—not two—were in filtrated into the Saigon press corps to spy on the newsmen, official sources conceded today.

headline: U.S. Denies Violation
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 29—The United States affirmed today that it sends reconnaissance planes over North Vietnam with fighter escorts, but denied that this violated the 1968 understand ing that halted the bombing raids.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Aide Rules Out Any Forced Concessions
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 31 (UPI)—The chief adviser of the North Vietnamese delegation at the peace talks here returned to day from consultations in Hanoi and said that his Gov ernment was ready for seri ous negotiations. However, he said that Hanoi would make no concessions at the negotiating table under United States military pres sure.

headline: Nixon to Decide in Month On Israel's Arms Requests
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — While insisting that he was not partial to either side in the continuing conflict in the Mid dle East, President Nixon said this evening that he would decide within a month how many more weapons the United States would sell to Israel.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Denies Agents Posed as Newsmen To Spy on the Press
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30—The United States Mission said in a statement issued here today that four agents fraudu lently accredited as newsmen had been on a mission “com pletely unrelated to the local Vietnamese and foreign press corps or their activities.”

headline: BATTLE IN VIETNAM NOW IN QUESTION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 31 (AP)—Offi cers said today that reports yesterday of a major battle be tween United States soldiers and enemy battalions near Tay ninh had been made by a unit commander and that “we are not convinced” of the accuracy of the reports.

headline: Defense Nears End of Chicago 7 Case
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 30—The de fense in the Chicago conspiracy trial neared the end of its case today in a session marked by the appearance of several prominent witnesses.
author: By J. Antiiony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Marine Killed in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) —Lance Cpl. Erick W. Beattie of Staten Island, a marine, has been killed in action in Viet nam, the Pentagon announced today.

headline: The Washington Record
Earlier Clashes Over the North Conceded
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 — The United States com mand acknowledged today that there had been periodic air‐to ground engagements in North Vietnam since the bombing halt 15 months ago that had not been made public because they were considered to be “insig nificant.”
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times
